config_defs.name: input.data.format
config_defs.documentation: Sets the input Kafka record value format. Valid entries are AVRO, JSON_SR, PROTOBUF, or JSON. Note that you need to have Confluent Cloud Schema Registry configured if using a schema-based message format like AVRO, JSON_SR, and PROTOBUF.

config_defs.name: connection.url
config_defs.group: How should we connect to your Elasticsearch Service?
config_defs.documentation: Elasticsearch Service connection URI (e.g. https://123123.us-east-1.aws.found.io:9243).

config_defs.name: connection.username
config_defs.group: How should we connect to your Elasticsearch Service?
config_defs.documentation: The username used to authenticate with Elasticsearch Service.

config_defs.name: connection.password
config_defs.group: How should we connect to your Elasticsearch Service?
config_defs.documentation: The password used to authenticate with Elasticsearch Service.

config_defs.name: elastic.security.protocol
config_defs.documentation: This should be set to SSL if you want to enable PKI auth with SSL support. Otherwise all ssl configs are ignored. Note that the connector will still use SSL if https is used.

config_defs.name: elastic.https.ssl.keystore.file
config_defs.documentation: The key store file. This is optional for client and can be used for two-way authentication for client.

config_defs.name: elastic.https.ssl.key.password
config_defs.documentation: The password of the private key in the key store file. This is required for clients only if two-way authentication is configured.

config_defs.name: elastic.https.ssl.keystore.password
config_defs.documentation: The store password for the key store file. This is optional for client and only needed if 'ssl.keystore.location' is configured.  Key store password is not supported for PEM format.

config_defs.name: elastic.https.ssl.keystore.type
config_defs.documentation: The file format of the key store file. This is optional for client.

config_defs.name: elastic.https.ssl.truststore.file
config_defs.documentation: The Truststore file with the certificates of the trusted CAs.

config_defs.name: elastic.https.ssl.truststore.password
config_defs.documentation: The password for the trust store file. If a password is not set, trust store file configured will still be used, but integrity checking is disabled. Trust store password is not supported for PEM format.

config_defs.name: elastic.https.ssl.truststore.type
config_defs.documentation: The file format of the trust store file.

config_defs.name: elastic.https.ssl.keymanager.algorithm
config_defs.documentation: The algorithm used by key manager factory for SSL connections.

config_defs.name: elastic.https.ssl.trustmanager.algorithm
config_defs.documentation: The algorithm used by trust manager factory for SSL connections.

config_defs.name: elastic.https.ssl.endpoint.identification.algorithm
config_defs.documentation: The endpoint identification algorithm to validate server hostname using server certificate.

config_defs.name: external.resource.usage
config_defs.documentation: The type of external resource the connector writes to, such as indices, datastreams or aliases. Valid options are INDEX, DATASTREAM, ALIAS_INDEX, ALIAS_DATASTREAM, and DISABLED. When set to DISABLED, the connector will auto-create indices or datastreams based on the topic name and datastream configurations.

config_defs.name: topic.to.external.resource.mapping
config_defs.documentation: A list of topic-to-resource mappings in the format 'topic:resource'. If specified, the connector will use the provided resource name (index, data stream, or alias) instead of the topic name for writing to Elasticsearch. The resource must exist in Elasticsearch before configuring the connector. The type of resource (index, data stream, or alias) is determined by the 'external.resource.usage' configuration.

config_defs.name: data.stream.type
config_defs.documentation: Describes the generic type of data to be written to a data stream. The default value is `none`, indicating that the connector will write to regular indices. If set, this configuration will be used alongside data.stream.dataset to construct the data stream name in the form of {``data.stream.type``}-{``data.stream.dataset``}-{``data.stream.namespace``}. Possible values are `logs`, `metrics`, `none`, and custom index templates defined in the destination cluster are also supported.

config_defs.name: data.stream.dataset
config_defs.documentation: Describes the data ingested and its structure to be written to a data stream. This can be any arbitrary string, provided it is no longer than 100 characters, in all lowercase, and does not contain spaces or any special characters ``/\*"<>|,#:-``. If no value is set, the connector writes to regular indices. If set, this configuration will be used alongside data.stream.type to construct the data stream name in the form of {``data.stream.type``}-{``data.stream.dataset``}-{``data.stream.namespace``}.

config_defs.name: data.stream.namespace
config_defs.documentation: Generic name describing a user-configurable arbitrary grouping for writing to a data stream. It can be any string up to 100 characters, in lowercase, without spaces or special characters (`/\*"<>|,#:-`). If unset, the connector writes to regular indices. When set, it is used with `data.stream.type` and `data.stream.dataset` to form the data stream name in the format `{data.stream.type}-{data.stream.dataset}-{data.stream.namespace}`. Default is `${topic}`, which means the topic name.

config_defs.name: data.stream.timestamp.field
config_defs.documentation: All documents sent to a data stream need an ``@timestamp`` field with values of type ``date`` or ``date_nanos``. Otherwise, the document  will not be sent. If multiple fields are provided, the first field listed that also appears in the record will be used. If this configuration is left empty, all of the documents will use the Kafka record timestamp as the ``@timestamp`` field value. Note that ``@timestamp`` still needs to be explicitly listed if records already contain this field.

config_defs.name: key.ignore
config_defs.documentation: Whether to ignore the record key for the purpose of forming the Elasticsearch document ID. When this is set to true, document IDs will be generated as topic+partition+offset taken from the record. When this is set to false, the record key will be used as the Elasticsearch document ID.

config_defs.name: topic.key.ignore
config_defs.documentation: List of topics for which ``key.ignore`` should be ``true``.

config_defs.name: schema.ignore
config_defs.documentation: Whether to ignore schemas during indexing. When this is set to true, the record schema will be ignored for the purpose of registering an Elasticsearch mapping. Elasticsearch will infer the mapping from the data (dynamic mapping needs to be enabled by the user).

config_defs.name: topic.schema.ignore
config_defs.documentation: List of topics for which ``schema.ignore`` should be ``true``.

config_defs.name: compact.map.entries
config_defs.documentation: Defines how map entries with string keys within record values should be written to JSON. When this is set to true, these entries are written compactly as "entryKey": "entryValue". Otherwise, map entries with string keys are written as a nested document {"key": "entryKey", "value": "entryValue"}.

config_defs.name: write.method
config_defs.documentation: Method used for writing data to Elasticsearch, and one of INSERT or UPSERT. The default method is INSERT, in which the connector constructs a document from the record value and inserts that document into Elasticsearch, completely replacing any existing document with the same ID; this matches previous behavior. The UPSERT method will create a new document if one with the specified ID does not yet exist, or will update an existing document with the same ID by adding/replacing only those fields present in the record value. The UPSERT method may require additional time and resources of Elasticsearch, so consider increasing the read.timeout.ms and decreasing the batch.size configuration properties.

config_defs.name: behavior.on.null.values
config_defs.documentation: How to handle records with a non-null key and a null value (i.e. Kafka tombstone records). Valid options are ignore, delete, and fail. Ignore will skip the record. Delete will delete the record. Fail will fail the connector.

config_defs.name: behavior.on.malformed.documents
config_defs.documentation: How to handle records that Elasticsearch rejects due to some malformation of the document itself, such as an index mapping conflict, a field name containing illegal characters, or a record with a missing id. 'ignore' will skip the bad records and 'fail' will fail the connector.

config_defs.name: drop.invalid.message
config_defs.documentation: Whether to drop a record if it cannot be converted to an Elasticsearch document.

config_defs.name: batch.size
config_defs.documentation: The number of records to process as a batch when writing to Elasticsearch.

config_defs.name: linger.ms
config_defs.documentation: Linger time in milliseconds for batching. Records that arrive in between request transmissions are batched into a single bulk indexing request, based on the batch.size configuration. Normally this only occurs under load when records arrive faster than they can be sent out. However, it may be desirable to reduce the number of requests even under light load and benefit from bulk indexing. This setting helps accomplish that - when a pending batch is not full, rather than immediately sending it out the task will wait up to the given delay to allow other records to be added so that they can be batched into a single request.

config_defs.name: flush.timeout.ms
config_defs.documentation: The timeout in milliseconds to use for periodic flushing, and when waiting for buffer space to be made available by completed requests as records are added. If this timeout is exceeded the task will fail.

config_defs.name: connection.compression
config_defs.documentation: Whether to use GZip compression on HTTP connection to ElasticSearch. To make this setting to work the http.compression setting also needs to be enabled at the Elasticsearch nodes before using it.

config_defs.name: read.timeout.ms
config_defs.documentation: How long to wait in milliseconds for the Elasticsearch server to send a response. The task fails if any read operation times out.

config_defs.name: external.version.header
config_defs.documentation: Header name to pull value for external versioning, defaults to using the kafka record offset. Must have a numeric value.

config_defs.name: use.autogenerated.ids
config_defs.documentation: Specifies whether to use auto-generated Elasticsearch document IDs for insertion requests. Note that this setting removes exactly once guarantees, and message delivery will be at least once. This only applies if the write method is set to `INSERT`. When set to `true`, the `Ignore Key mode` option will also be ignored when sending data to Elasticsearch.

config_defs.name: connector.class
config_defs.group: How should we connect to your data?

config_defs.name: name
config_defs.group: How should we connect to your data?
config_defs.documentation: Sets a name for your connector.

config_defs.name: tasks.max
config_defs.group: Number of tasks for this connector
config_defs.documentation: Maximum number of tasks for the connector.

config_defs.name: kafka.auth.mode
config_defs.documentation: Kafka Authentication mode. It can be one of KAFKA_API_KEY or SERVICE_ACCOUNT. It defaults to KAFKA_API_KEY mode.

config_defs.name: kafka.api.key
config_defs.documentation: Kafka API Key. Required when kafka.auth.mode==KAFKA_API_KEY.

connector_configs.name: confluent.topic.bootstrap.servers
connector_configs.value: Placeholder value to pass connector validations

config_defs.name: kafka.service.account.id
config_defs.documentation: The Service Account that will be used to generate the API keys to communicate with Kafka Cluster.

config_defs.name: kafka.api.secret
config_defs.documentation: Secret associated with Kafka API key. Required when kafka.auth.mode==KAFKA_API_KEY.

config_defs.name: topics
config_defs.group: Which topics do you want to get data from?
config_defs.documentation: Identifies the topic name or a comma-separated list of topic names.

config_defs.name: max.poll.interval.ms
config_defs.documentation: The maximum delay between subsequent consume requests to Kafka. This configuration property may be used to improve the performance of the connector, if the connector cannot send records to the sink system. Defaults to 300000 milliseconds (5 minutes).

config_defs.name: max.poll.records
config_defs.documentation: The maximum number of records to consume from Kafka in a single request. This configuration property may be used to improve the performance of the connector, if the connector cannot send records to the sink system. Defaults to 500 records.

config_defs.name: errors.tolerance
config_defs.documentation: Use this property if you would like to configure the connector's error handling behavior. WARNING: This property should be used with CAUTION for SOURCE CONNECTORS as it may lead to dataloss. If you set this property to 'all', the connector will not fail on errant records, but will instead log them (and send to DLQ for Sink Connectors) and continue processing. If you set this property to 'none', the connector task will fail on errant records.

config_defs.name: errors.deadletterqueue.topic.name
config_defs.group: Which topics do you want to get data from?
config_defs.documentation: The name of the topic to be used as the dead letter queue (DLQ) for messages that result in an error when processed by this sink connector, or its transformations or converters. Defaults to 'dlq-${connector}' if not set. The DLQ topic will be created automatically if it does not exist. You can provide ``${connector}`` in the value to use it as a placeholder for the logical cluster ID.

config_defs.name: schema.context.name
config_defs.documentation: Add a schema context name. A schema context represents an independent scope in Schema Registry. It is a separate sub-schema tied to topics in different Kafka clusters that share the same Schema Registry instance. If not used, the connector uses the default schema configured for Schema Registry in your Confluent Cloud environment.

config_defs.name: input.data.format
config_defs.documentation: Sets the input Kafka record value format. Valid entries are AVRO, JSON_SR, PROTOBUF, JSON or BYTES. Note that you need to have Confluent Cloud Schema Registry configured if using a schema-based message format like AVRO, JSON_SR, and PROTOBUF.

config_defs.name: value.converter.schemas.enable
config_defs.documentation: Include schemas within each of the serialized values. Input messages must contain `schema` and `payload` fields and may not contain additional fields. For plain JSON data, set this to `false`. Applicable for JSON Converter.

config_defs.name: value.converter.replace.null.with.default
config_defs.documentation: Whether to replace fields that have a default value and that are null to the default value. When set to true, the default value is used, otherwise null is used. Applicable for JSON Converter.

config_defs.name: value.converter.ignore.default.for.nullables
config_defs.documentation: When set to true, this property ensures that the corresponding record in Kafka is NULL, instead of showing the default column value. Applicable for AVRO,PROTOBUF and JSON_SR Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.scrub.invalid.names
config_defs.documentation: Whether to scrub invalid names by replacing invalid characters with valid characters. Applicable for Avro and Protobuf Converters.

config_defs.name: auto.restart.on.user.error
config_defs.documentation: Enable connector to automatically restart on user-actionable errors.

config_defs.name: value.converter.enhanced.avro.schema.support
config_defs.documentation: Enable enhanced schema support to preserve package information and Enums. Applicable for Avro Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.connect.meta.data
config_defs.documentation: Allow the Connect converter to add its metadata to the output schema. Applicable for Avro Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.enhanced.protobuf.schema.support
config_defs.documentation: Enable enhanced schema support to preserve package information. Applicable for Protobuf Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.generate.index.for.unions
config_defs.documentation: Whether to generate an index suffix for unions. Applicable for Protobuf Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.int.for.enums
config_defs.documentation: Whether to represent enums as integers. Applicable for Protobuf Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.optional.for.nullables
config_defs.documentation: Whether nullable fields should be specified with an optional label. Applicable for Protobuf Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.generate.struct.for.nulls
config_defs.documentation: Whether to generate a struct variable for null values. Applicable for Protobuf Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.wrapper.for.nullables
config_defs.documentation: Whether nullable fields should use primitive wrapper messages. Applicable for Protobuf Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.wrapper.for.raw.primitives
config_defs.documentation: Whether a wrapper message should be interpreted as a raw primitive at root level. Applicable for Protobuf Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.object.additional.properties
config_defs.documentation: Whether to allow additional properties for object schemas. Applicable for JSON_SR Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.use.optional.for.nonrequired
config_defs.documentation: Whether to set non-required properties to be optional. Applicable for JSON_SR Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.decimal.format
config_defs.documentation:
Specify the JSON/JSON_SR serialization format for Connect DECIMAL logical type values with two allowed literals:
BASE64 to serialize DECIMAL logical types as base64 encoded binary data and
NUMERIC to serialize Connect DECIMAL logical type values in JSON/JSON_SR as a number representing the decimal value.

config_defs.name: value.converter.auto.register.schemas
config_defs.documentation: Specify if the Serializer should attempt to register the Schema.

config_defs.name: value.converter.use.latest.version
config_defs.documentation: Use latest version of schema in subject for serialization when auto.register.schemas is false.

config_defs.name: value.converter.latest.compatibility.strict
config_defs.documentation: Verify latest subject version is backward compatible when `use.latest.version` is `true`.

config_defs.name: key.converter.key.subject.name.strategy
config_defs.documentation: How to construct the subject name for key schema registration.

config_defs.name: value.converter.value.subject.name.strategy
config_defs.documentation: Determines how to construct the subject name under which the value schema is registered with Schema Registry.

config_defs.name: value.converter.reference.subject.name.strategy
config_defs.documentation: Set the subject reference name strategy for value. Valid entries are DefaultReferenceSubjectNameStrategy or QualifiedReferenceSubjectNameStrategy. Note that the subject reference name strategy can be selected only for PROTOBUF format with the default strategy being DefaultReferenceSubjectNameStrategy.

config_defs.name: value.converter.allow.optional.map.keys
config_defs.documentation: Allow optional string map key when converting from Connect Schema to Avro Schema. Applicable for Avro Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.flatten.singleton.unions
config_defs.documentation: Whether to flatten singleton unions. Applicable for Avro and JSON_SR Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.optional.for.proto2
config_defs.documentation: Whether proto2 optionals are supported. Applicable for Protobuf Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.flatten.unions
config_defs.documentation: Whether to flatten unions (oneofs). Applicable for Protobuf Converters.

config_defs.name: header.converter
config_defs.documentation: The converter class for the headers. This is used to serialize and deserialize the headers of the messages.

config_defs.name: consumer.override.auto.offset.reset
config_defs.documentation: Defines the behavior of the consumer when there is no committed position (which occurs when the group is first initialized) or when an offset is out of range. You can choose either to reset the position to the earliest offset (the default) or the latest offset. You can also select none if you would rather set the initial offset yourself and you are willing to handle out of range errors manually. More details: https://docs.confluent.io/platform/current/installation/configuration/consumer-configs.html#auto-offset-reset

config_defs.name: consumer.override.isolation.level
config_defs.documentation: Controls how to read messages written transactionally. If set to read_committed, consumer.poll() will only return transactional messages which have been committed. If set to read_uncommitted (the default), consumer.poll() will return all messages, even transactional messages which have been aborted. Non-transactional messages will be returned unconditionally in either mode.  More details: https://docs.confluent.io/platform/current/installation/configuration/consumer-configs.html#isolation-level

config_defs.name: topics.regex
config_defs.group: Which topics do you want to get data from?
config_defs.documentation: A regular expression that matches the names of the topics to consume from. This is useful when you want to consume from multiple topics that match a certain pattern without having to list them all individually.
